title: Welcome to the CBCS Coding Club!
text:
Welcome to the CBCS Coding Club!



Our vision
CBCS Coding Club is a student-led group that aims to provide a common space for coding and programming geeks and enthusiasts alike to interact and share their passion about coding. The CBCS Coding Club comprises Higher Degree by Research (HDR) students and Early Career Researchers (ECRs) in the Centre for Biodiversity and Conservation Science (CBCS) as well as the School of the Environment (SENV) at the University of Queensland. The club‚Äôs vision is to provide a space for the gathering of like-minded coders and programmers in the fields of conservation and environmental science regardless of their levels of coding expertise.


Join us!
üíª Do you love coding?
üí° Are you interested in learning more about coding?
ü§î Do you want to improve your coding skills but don‚Äôt know where to start?
üî• Do you feel the burning urge to geek out about your favorite package or function?
If your answer is yes to any of those questions, then Join Coding Club!

title: CBCS Coding Club
text:
Our vision
CBCS Coding Club is a student-led group that aims to provide a common space for coding and programming geeks and enthusiasts alike to interact and share their passion about coding. The CBCS Coding Club comprises Higher Degree by Research (HDR) students and Early Career Researchers (ECRs) in CBCS as well as the School of the Environment (SENV) at the University of Queensland. The club‚Äôs vision is to provide a space for the gathering of like-minded coders and programmers in the fields of conservation and environmental science regardless of their levels of coding expertise.

title: CBCS Coding Club
text:
Join us!
Do you love coding? üíª

title: Who are we?
text: The CBCS Coding Club comprises a group of students and early career researchers in CBCS and SENV at the University of Queensland. Coding Club is currently co-led by:

title: Who are we?
text:
Kristine (Tin) Buenafe



   

I am a PhD candidate from the Philippines working on climate-smart marine conservation planning with a particular focus in the high seas. While I enjoy coding all-day, working to develop reproducible tools and frameworks used to facilitate the uptake of climate-smart approaches in on-the-ground, applied conservation planning approaches, I wish to continue navigating the science-policy interface, particularly in relation to the Biodiversity Beyond National Jurisdiction (BBNJ) Agreement. I love trying out so many different new hobbies, but only stick to a couple, like reading sci-fi and fantasy books, watching basketball, playing video games.

title: Who are we?
text:
Yi Fei Chung



  

Fei is a PhD candidate in the School of the Environment at The University of Queensland. His research focuses on policy settings that can enhance climate adaptation while also developing methods to account for the effects of climate extremes in these policies. He primarily uses programming for applications ranging from simulating species persistence across landscapes to modelling alternative policy scenarios.

title: Who are we?
text:
Rosa Mar Dominguez-Martinez



  

I‚Äôm a PhD candidate at the University of Queensland who somehow went from growing up in the Spanish mountains to becoming completely obsessed with the ocean (turns out, following the sun was a good life strategy). Now I spend my days wrestling with massive datasets in R, creating visualizations that hopefully make sense, and investigating how international seafood trade impacts marine life. My PhD focuses on the sustainability of global seafood supply chains, particularly the trade of threatened species as seafood. When I‚Äôm not coding or untangling the complexities of fish economics, I‚Äôm dreaming up novel ways to make our seafood consumption more sustainable.

title: Past Meet-ups
text:
CBCS Coding Club meet-ups are led by different folks of different coding backgrounds and career levels. Topics are broad and encompass different programming languages (R, python), coding skills (spatial data analysis and visualization, data wrangling, writing shiny apps), and coding tools (VS Code, HPC).
If you‚Äôre interested in leading a meet-up, feel free to contact any of the current Coding Club co-leads!

Recordings of past meet-ups

title: Rule 1
text:
Joining Coding Club is easy, but our members also follow some simple (and straightforward) rules:

Rule 1
Be nice. Be respectful. Be inclusive. üë•


Rule 2
We‚Äôll all learn from each other. It‚Äôs a give and take. ü§ù


Rule 3
We are not required to host workshops. There are better resources for these, and we would gladly point you to these resources if needed. üìî
Coding club is just as good as its members. So if you like what Coding Club is doing, support the club by participating in meet-ups and events and being more active.

title: Coding Resources
text:
Part of the CBCS Coding Club‚Äôs initiative is to compile a list of different coding resources that could support environmental and conservation research. This compilation is ‚Äòalive‚Äô, and so if there are any resources that you think are missing from the list below (we know that we are missing lots!), please do contact any of the current coding club leads and we can add them.

Databases
Conservation and environmental researchers often use the same open-access data. Here are some of the databases that are often used in these research fields, some of which can be accessed directly through programming packages.



IUCN Red List
There are lots of different R packages that can be used to access the IUCN Red List‚Äôs data repository.

iucnredList
rredlist
iucnr
red





World Database on Protected Areas (WDPA)

wdpar






Australia‚Äôs Terrestrial Ecosystem Network (TERN)
Explore TERN‚Äôs data portals and services.

ausplotsR
WildObsR





Marine Regions of the world
Get the the boundaries and shapefiles you need for exclusive economic zones (EEZ), areas beyond national jurisdiction, global oceans and seas, large marine ecosystems of the world (MEOW), Longhurst provinces, and many more!

mregions2






A collection of different climate data products from the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project 6 (CMIP6)

Earth System Grid Federation: global (raw)
WorldClim: global (processed)
BioORACLE through biooracler in R pyo_oracle in Python and : global, marine (processed)
NARCliM: high-resolution climate model data for New South Wales and Australia
LongPaddock: regional, high-resolution climate model data for Queensland

Here are some R packages that could help wrangle climate outputs.

hotrstuff: R package in development led by Tin Buenafe
rcdo





A collection of different fisheries-related products

Global Fishing Watch

gfwr is an R package for accessing the GFW data through an API (application programming interface) key

FishStatJ to access FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations)‚Äôs Fisheries and Aquaculture statistics
ARTIS is a database that provides the first global estimates of seafood species and nutrient trade flows





Packages
These are some of the most common packages used in a lot of analysis in conservation and environmental research.

rnaturalearth to access natural earth vector map data (e.g., administrative boundaries and borders of countries, coastlines). Some key functions include:

ne_countries()
ne_download()

countrycode for standardizing country names
janitor for cleaning up messy data



Online books
If you‚Äôre the type to learn more by reading textbooks, here are some great online textbooks that you can read.

R for Data Science (2e)
Advance R
Mastering Shiny



Websites and online resource hubs
There are thousands of different packages in different programming languages, and sometimes, the package just doesn‚Äôt have great documentation. Fear not! There are some websites and online resource hubs that dive deep into some of these packages and their different functions.

R Graph Gallery

R Graph Gallery Book

title: Join us
text:
We are an inclusive bunch, so to be part of the growing CBCS Coding Club community, all you need to do is ask and email the Current Co-leads to be added.
For any questions regarding the Centre for Biodiversity and Conservation Science, email our Centre Coordinator, Kate Donnelly at cbcs-admin@uq.edu.au.
